skill.name: pymoo
skill.description: Multi-objective optimization framework. NSGA-II, NSGA-III, MOEA/D, Pareto fronts, constraint handling, benchmarks (ZDT, DTLZ), for engineering design and optimization problems.
skill.summary: Multi-objective optimization framework. NSGA-II, NSGA-III, MOEA/D, Pareto fronts, constraint handlin...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate multi-objective optimization documentation skill. All 315 static findings are false positives. The scanner misinterpreted markdown code formatting backticks as shell commands, optimization algorithm names (NSGA-II, NSGA-III) as cryptographic algorithms, and optimization terminology as security threats. Python scripts contain standard pymoo optimization examples with no malicious code.

content.user_title: Solve multi-objective optimization with evolutionary algorithms
content.value_statement: Multi-objective optimization involves finding trade-off solutions when multiple conflicting objectives must be satisfied. This skill provides comprehensive access to pymoo algorithms including NSGA-II, NSGA-III, and MOEA/D for finding Pareto-optimal solutions and visualizing trade-off fronts.
actual_capabilities: Run single and multi-objective optimization using NSGA-II, NSGA-III, MOEA/D, GA, DE, PSO
Define custom optimization problems with ElementwiseProblem class
Apply constraint handling techniques including penalty methods and feasibility-first approaches
Visualize Pareto fronts using Scatter plots, PCP, Heatmaps, and Petal diagrams
Apply multi-criteria decision making methods including PseudoWeights and compromise programming
Benchmark algorithms using standard test problems (ZDT, DTLZ, WFG)
limitations: Requires pymoo library installation (uv pip install pymoo)
Gradient-based optimization not supported; uses population-based evolutionary approaches
Many-objective optimization (4+ objectives) requires NSGA-III with reference directions
Results depend on proper problem formulation and algorithm parameter tuning

use_cases.title: Engineering design optimization
use_cases.description: Find optimal trade-offs between competing design objectives like cost, weight, strength, and performance.

use_cases.title: Model hyperparameter tuning
use_cases.description: Optimize multiple conflicting metrics like accuracy, inference speed, and model complexity simultaneously.

use_cases.title: Algorithm comparison studies
use_cases.description: Benchmark optimization algorithms on standard test problems to evaluate convergence and diversity.

prompt_templates.title: Basic multi-objective optimization
prompt_templates.prompt: Optimize the ZDT1 benchmark problem with NSGA-II to find the Pareto front. Use 100 population size and 200 generations.

prompt_templates.title: Custom problem definition
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a custom two-variable, two-objective problem where f1 = x[0]^2 + x[1]^2 and f2 = (x[0]-1)^2 + (x[1]-1)^2 with bounds [0, 5] for both variables.

prompt_templates.title: Constraint handling
prompt_templates.prompt: Solve a constrained multi-objective optimization problem using the penalty method with NSGA-II. Show how to check feasibility of solutions.

prompt_templates.title: Many-objective visualization
prompt_templates.prompt: Run NSGA-III on DTLZ2 with 5 objectives and visualize the results using a Parallel Coordinate Plot to show trade-offs across all objectives.

output_examples.input: Optimize ZDT1 with NSGA-II to find Pareto front
output: Visualization: Scatter plot showing convex Pareto front
Ready for use with any pymoo algorithm
Constraint violation tracking via CV (constraint violation) array

best_practices: Set random seed (seed=1) for reproducible optimization results
Normalize objectives to [0,1] range before applying decision-making methods
Compare obtained fronts with true Pareto fronts when benchmark problems are used
anti_patterns: Using NSGA-II for many-objective problems (4+ objectives) - use NSGA-III instead
Ignoring constraint formulation (must be g <= 0 for inequality, h = 0 for equality)
Running optimization without visualizing results - always plot Pareto fronts

faq.question: What is the difference between NSGA-II and NSGA-III?
faq.answer: NSGA-II handles 2-3 objectives efficiently. NSGA-III is designed for 4+ objectives using reference directions.

faq.question: How do I choose between NSGA-II and MOEA/D?
faq.answer: NSGA-II is general-purpose for well-distributed fronts. MOEA/D excels when decomposition into scalar subproblems is effective.

faq.question: What termination criteria should I use?
faq.answer: Use ('n_gen', N) for generations, ('n_eval', N) for evaluations, or tolerance-based termination for convergence.

faq.question: How do I extract the best solution from Pareto front?
faq.answer: Use PseudoWeights with preference weights, or knee point selection for balanced trade-offs.

faq.question: Can I use this for discrete or mixed-variable problems?
faq.answer: Yes, pymoo supports binary, discrete, continuous, and mixed-variable problems with appropriate operators.

faq.question: How do I visualize results with more than 3 objectives?
faq.answer: Use Parallel Coordinate Plot (PCP) for 4+ objectives to show all dimensions simultaneously.
